body:
Hi,

if I'm understanding your use case correctly, this isn't currently supported in the ObjC library. But let's double check: you're trying to make a gRPC connection from a Mac (_not_ iOS) to another server, right?
Sorry I wasn't clear, I am building an iOS app and am trying to specify the TLS certificate inside that app.
No worries! And the certificate you're trying to use identifies the server (your secure domain), right? _Not_ the client app, correct?
Yes that is correct

Ok then, we're on the same page now :)

> I tried just appending my certs to that file but it didn't seem to work

This should have worked, even if it's not an ideal solution... Is your cert on PEM format? What did the library output in the logs console when trying to connect? What's the result if you replace the whole contents of the file with your cert?

The ideal solution would be to use [this method](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/objective-c/tests/InteropTestsLocalSSL.m#L57), which was created for calling test servers. But if adding your cert to the default file doesn't work, this shouldn't either!

I'm using the library via cocoapods, it seems that there are updates in the repo that aren't in the cocoapods version (Also I can't access the private headers from my app.)

But when I replaced the roots.pem with my cert I got this error:

```
E0918 11:35:40.167109000 2953924608 security_connector.c:447] Missing selected ALPN property.
E0918 11:35:40.167695000 2953924608 secure_transport_setup.c:118] Peer check failed.
E0918 11:35:40.167829000 2953924608 secure_channel_create.c:82] Secure transport setup failed with error 2.
```

Is there some server configuration that is needed to make this work? I also noticed differences in the files on the repo from the 0.6 version on cocoapods, in things like GRPCSecureChannel. Should I try using the source straight from the repo?

Oh, I see. Yes, I'm close to sending the next release to Cocoapods (the last one with breaking changes :) ), so please clone (or submodule) this repo and tell Cocoapods to use it instead of v0.6 (and to use Protobuf version "3.0.0-alpha-4.1"). To do that, add the following lines to your Podfile:

``` ruby
pod 'Protobuf', "3.0.0-alpha-4.1"
pod 'gRPC', :path => "path/to/the/root/of/this/repo"
```

This way we won't be debugging old code.

I actually am working on doing that now, but now I am getting a crash on a mutex lock. I built and installed the grpc-objc plugin from source as the one I installed via homebrew seemed to compile the old version.

Ah, yes! Sorry, that's Issue https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/3364. If you checkout the repo before commit https://github.com/grpc/grpc/commit/131f6edafa1a281604fffc24019dcb99134eec9f it doesn't happen.

`E0922 15:48:17.435238000 2953924608 security_connector.c:451] Missing selected ALPN property.
E0922 15:48:17.435632000 2953924608 secure_transport_setup.c:123] Peer check failed.
E0922 15:48:17.435642000 2953924608 secure_channel_create.c:85] Secure transport setup failed with error 2.`

Ok so I am now on version 0.7.0 (The commit before the one you posted), but still getting this error. We have the x509 cert from the server when we are in ssl_handshaker_extract_peer but the alpn and npn methods return null. 

The server is using grpc-go I believe, and we have a go based client that is able to connect to it. This is the code they are using:

```
    creds, err := credentials.NewClientTLSFromFile("***certname***.cert", "***domain_name***")
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatalf("> failed to create transport authenticator: %s", err)
    }

    conn, err := grpc.Dial(routerEndpoint, grpc.WithTransportCredentials(creds))
```

They just have to set the client TLS certificate and domain, then connect with Dial.

Basically using our old stack the iOS app could connect and work, but the new stack requires TLS and I can no longer connect.

It _might_ be that this `.cert` file can't replace the default `certs.pem` file...

Hey @jboeuf, do you know if a `.cert` file with an x509 cert can work as a substitute of the `certs.pem` file we use by default? Or are they completely different things?
@jcanizales Do you have an estimate on when the cocoapods version will be updated (Just a general guess is fine, next few weeks or longer?) And will that be with version 0.11? Or an earlier one?

Sorry I dropped the ball on this one...

@jcanizales Indeed, an X509 PEM (which is text/base64 as opposed to DER which is binary) encoded cert can be used as a substitute for our roots.pem. roots.pem is just a list of PEM encoded certs.

@jclardy It looks like (90% sure) your issue does not come from the cert but from your server TLS implementation that does not support ALPN or NPN (needed for an HTTP2 stack like gRPC):

```
E0918 11:35:40.167109000 2953924608 security_connector.c:447] Missing selected ALPN property.
E0918 11:35:40.167695000 2953924608 secure_transport_setup.c:118] Peer check failed.
E0918 11:35:40.167829000 2953924608 secure_channel_create.c:82] Secure transport setup failed with error 2.
```

Here, the TLS handshake actually worked OK (the server cert was validated with your supplied root) but your server did not send its ALPN or NPN version. Which server are you using? A server from the gRPC package?
@jclardy I'm actually submitting v. 0.11 to the Cocoapods main repo either today or early next week :)
@jboeuf They have a go client that's connecting successfully, so the fingers point at something wrong in the client.

Maybe the go client does not enforce ALPN...

```
Julien.
```

On Fri, Sep 25, 2015 at 10:32 AM, Jorge Canizales notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @jboeuf https://github.com/jboeuf They have a go client that's
> connecting successfully, so the fingers point at something wrong in the
> client.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/3363#issuecomment-143295980.
But then this would show up on our interop tests, and e.g. the C client and Ruby client (which wraps C, like the Objective-C one) are currently communicating successfully with a Go server.

Is the server our Go server?

On Fri, Sep 25, 2015 at 10:44 AM, Jorge Canizales notifications@github.com
wrote:

> But then this would show up on our interop tests, and e.g. the C client
> and Ruby client (which wraps C, like the Objective-C one) are currently
> communicating successfully with a Go server.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/3363#issuecomment-143300033.
@jclardy can you find out how's your server being configured exactly?
@jcanizales @jboeuf it is the Go one, do the interop tests include tls connections? We had a working unsecured connection before moving to TLS.

Interesting. I'm pretty sure they do. @yang-g will know for sure: 
Yang, do we have end-to-end test with TLS from a C-based client to a Go server?

We have interop tests with tls between all c-based clients to go server.

On Fri, Sep 25, 2015 at 2:01 PM, jboeuf notifications@github.com wrote:

> Interesting. I'm pretty sure they do. @yang-g https://github.com/yang-g
> will know for sure:
> Yang, do we have end-to-end test with TLS from a C-based client to a Go
> server?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/3363#issuecomment-143353900.

> all c-based clients to go server

Except the Objective-C one :) because the infrastructure is completely different. But it still releases the Go server from suspicion.

@jclardy At this point I can just think of further tests to make, to investigate further:
- What's the error in the logs if you _don't_ replace the default roots.pem with your certificate?
- And if you _append_ your certificate to the end of it?
- And if you do the above but connecting to `grpc-test.sandbox.google.com` instead of your server?
@jclardy Also, with the current failure, can you put a breakpoint in ssl_check_peer (in security_connector.c) and give me the values in the peer?
@jcanizales When these logs are written, the certificate chaining check should have already passed (unless if there's a bug in our code).
Yeah, if he can't connect to `grpc-test.sandbox.google.com` with the default certs, then we have proof the problem is unrelated to his using a different cert, and we can try and debug there.
Any luck with these tests, @jclardy?
@jclardy @jcanizales see #5592 for setting client certificates (tls mutual authentication)
Hi @jclardy, were you ever able to solve the problem?
Removing GA label on this, but keeping the bug open.
